description.narrative: The programme seeks to support the implementation of the constitution in particular the Bill of Rights, transparence and accontability. It is also aims to supports the national response to gender based violence.

title.narrative: Case management display screen -High Court of Swaziland
Signed LOA UNDP and Judiciary of Swaziland

description.narrative: Fundamental principles and practices for good governance will be built for key national institutions for effective management of public resources, access to justice and information.
independent political entity
Human rights affairs

1. % of legal advisors in line ministries 2. # of state party reports compiled and submitted timely 3. # of key government officials trained in Public Finance Management 4. # of Anti Corruption Commission (ACC) and Swaziland Revenue Authority (SRA) staff trained in accountability and transparency issues, including Leadership Code of Conduct. 5. Functional electronic file system for court cases 6. # of Judiciary staff, police and law society members trained in addressing challenges in accessing justice 7.Legal aid framework developed 8.Number of cases reviewed by the Commission on Human Rights and Public Administration (CHRPA) 9.# of civic education interventions on the importance of equal participation and representation of all parts of society 10.# of people from under-represented groups trained in leadership and election campaigning 11. # of candidates from underrepresented groups that stand for national elections

comment.narrative: 1. 2008: Three (3) bills gazetted and Four (4) pieces of legislation have been reviewed. 2. Limited legal capacity in line ministries. 3. 2010: CEDAW and Second National Communications drafts in place. 4. 2010: 120 senior government officials have received training in Accountability and Integrity. 5. Aid Coordination Policy of 2000 in place. Excel-based data capture system for External Aid Management System exists but not operational. 6. 2010: No public servants received training in Public Financial Management systems or processes. 7. In 2010: no advocacy activities conducted on anti-corruption, transparency and accountability.

1.MPs and Public Officials capacity strengthened on the rights based approach and International conventions. 2.UPR Committee and CSO’s capacity strengthened on second UPR national state report 3.Human Rights Mainstreaming manual validated, approved and printed 4.Legislation and policy on Legal Aid approved by Cabinet. 5.Parliamentary Standing orders reviewed, aligned to the Constitution and adopted. 6.Portfolio Committee biannual plans developed. 7.Parliamentary legislative capacity strengthened 8.Parliamentary Legislative Manual Developed. 9.A blue print public service coordination mechanisms established. 10.Mapping exercise for public services available at local authority services identified. 11.Public service delivery gap analysis and citizen’s participation and satisfaction level on public service delivery facilitated. 12.Performance standards and benchmarks developed 13.Public Service delivery monitoring strengthened at Community level through the use of community score card and social accountability tools: 14.Public Service Charter for public services available at regional level developed, printed and disseminated. 15.E-constituency pilot project established 16.Anti-corruption campaigns in the four regions conducted 17.Prevention of Corruption Act Reviewed and tabled to Cabinet 18.Conduct an Inventory and mapping for e/m applications and services to produce a status report. 19.Design a corporate identity for the e/m Government brand and a Communication Strategy 20.Swaziland www.gov.sz portal strengthened. 21.Innovations Association of Swaziland capacity strengthened for effective participation on development and innovation programmes. 22.Launch of the Innovations Hub. 23.IAS Members capacitated on mobile applications development.

1. Ministry of Tinkhundla Parliament Portfolio Committee sensitised on the Rights based Approach and gender mainstreaming principles. This facilitated new appreciating for the importance of citizen’s engagement and continued advocacy for having decentralised services. 2. 40 Government Ministries and Civil society organisations trained on state reporting in preparation for the UPR. The Draft report has been prepared. Swaziland due to present a report in 2016. 3. The CHRPA has been engaged to facilitate the adoption of the Manual as one of the tools to be utilised by the Institution. Strategic partnership was established between the CHRPA and the Commission for Human Rights in South Africa. This enabled South South resulting on the Swaziland team being attached to the South affrican Commission for a week to learn on how to effectively manage a National Human Rights Institution.
4. High level Advocacy with the new Minister for Justice and Principal Secretary was facilitated on the Legal Aid Bill and Policy. This resulted in renewed commitment to table the bill and policy before Cabinet early 2016. 5. Parliament Standing Orders have been reviewed for alignment to the Constitution. Portfolio Committee currently reviewing second draft prior to finalisation. This should improve parliament operations and conduct of Parliamentarians. 6. The new Standing Orders recommend a restructuring of the Portfolio Committees. Development of portfolio plans has been re-phased to 2016 pending the restructuring of the Portfolio Committees. 7/8. Strengthening legislative capacity and legislative manual development rephrased to 2016. 9. A Coordination mechanisms for the regions was developed for enhanced coordination of public services at all levels of the governance system. The Coordination framework will be piloted and scaled up in the two regions prioritised in the new CPD. 10. Draft report on the public services offered by the Government at all levels has been facili

1. Provide Technical support for the development of a national E-procurement strategy. 2. Provide technical assistance from RSC for the development of a procurement agenda and capacity building 3. Develop and monitor regional development plans for effective decentralization of services 4. Establish a pay a bribe reporting website as means for mitigating corruption within public service delivery 5. Provide support for the branding of e-governance initiative 6. Develop public sector HIV Mainstreaming guidelines 7. Provide Technical Assistance for undertaking a national corruption perception survey 8. Provide technical and normative support for the development of tools and analysis of the public sector customer satisfaction survey 9. Support the preparation of the Status report on Human rights in Swaziland (Human Rights Baseline in Swaziland) 10. Provide technical support for conducting a sexual harassment study within public and private sector 11. Support consultations for the development of a Swaziland Governance Index 12. Provide Technical Support for the development of a Gender Equality Index 13. Support CANGO establishment of Key populations consortium 14. Provide technical support for the development of Key populations strategic plan 15. Support Parliament with the development of an interactive website 16. Strengthen capacity of Parliamentarians on the implementation of of the 2016 Standing Orders 17. Develop guidelines for Domestication of International Conventions 18. Support the roll out of the community score card for monitoring service delivery 19. Strengthen resource mobilization for the establishment of an e- Parliament; citizens participation in the local authority; access to justice

title.narrative: Strengthening National Capacities for Poverty Reduction

description.narrative: To support the development of evidence policy development, capacity development for data generation, women economic empowernment through promotion of entreprenuership and sustainable business management.

title.narrative: Mid Term Evaluation Report - THe Poverty Reduction PRogramme

description.narrative: Development of national frameworks including policies, systems and processes that promote the access and effective utilization of productive resources by the poor is key in the project implemntation.
capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration

1. Number of Sectors that have development plans formulated through the SWAPs 2. # of women entrepreneurs receiving support through mentorship programmes. 3. # of national and sectoral interventions supported for a coordinated and effectively managed attainment of MDGs through a more effective implementation of the PRSAP. 4. # of survey reports that have been printed and disseminated

comment.narrative: 1. Weak national planning and poverty reduction monitoring frameworks, systems and processes. 2. Four sector working groups established but not yet functional. 3. No national targets and monitoring mechanisms for attainment of individual MDGs. 4. Weak aid coordination and management mechanisms. 5. Limited capacity for national stakeholders (CSO) to generate, analyse and disseminate data and information.

1. Facilitate development of Sector Development Plans. 2. Support Development of the M&E system to tract NDS implementation 3. Support extensive application of the T21 model 4. Support translation of the NDS into Braille and Siswati 5. Support validation of the Aid Policy 6. Support development of the 2015 MDG Report 7. Support the launch of the Apex Body 8. Support leadership training of the Apex body

1. SWAp initiatives were postpone to 2016 giving time for budget preparation. 2. A consultancy firm was identified to develop the automated M&E system and is awaiting clearance from RSC. 3. Activity has been rescheduled to the first quarter of 2016. 4. Activity is awaiting for clearance from the Cabinet Office 5. Validation is awaiting finalisation of the reviewing process by the European Union. 6. The MDGR was developed, validate and printed. 7. Launch of the Apex Body was postponed to 2016. 8. The training was postponed to 2016 due to dispute in election processes.

1. Integration of the SDGs into the national development plans and programmes.
2. Increased systemic national planning capacities: NDS Action Plan; Macro modelling capacities; ministerial strategic plans. 3. National capacities strengthened for poverty reduction monitoring, planning and reporting through: the establishment of the National M&E System; (2017) Swaziland Household Income Expenditure Survey; and Data Ecosystem Mapping. 4. Diversification of the productive base through use of sustainable production technologies, credit facilities mechanisms; SME training.

title.narrative: Adaptation and Transboundary Waters Resource Management

description.narrative: Adapting national and transboundary water resource management in Swaziland to manage the expected impacts of climate change

title.narrative: Adapting national and trans-boundary water resource management Project Document
Constructed tap for provision of drinking water to school(s)- Adapatation National and Transboundary Water Resources Management in Swaziland to manage the expected impacts to climate change
Project Information Document for Swaziland SCCF CCA Project
Adaptaing national and Transboundary water resource management in Swaziland to manage the expected impacts of climate change

description.narrative: Adapting national and transboundary water resource management in Swaziland to manage the expected impacts of climate change.
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
1. Feasibility Report.

comment.narrative: 2010: Feasibility Study conducted

1. Rural vulnerable communities' livelihood capacities strengthened through integration of sustainable development in local initiatives. 2. Ecosystems restoration pilot project in place. 3. Increased capacity for climate change adaptation in transboundary settings for the national negotiations team. 4. Enhanced climate change adaptation advocacy: communication products and World Water Day

1 and 2: 56 community members mobilized and capacities to undertake income-generation activities; One pilot site with demonstrated ecosystem restoration through clearance of alien and invasive species and establishment of a nursery for indigenous trees; vegetable growing through use of a climate smart agriculture technology in 5 ha of land, which has been furnished with drip irrigation equipment; 80 bee-keeping hives, and; 4 fish ponds.
3. The Mainstreaming of CC Risks into National Policies Report was produced. UNDP supported the reengineering for high-level engagement by the country in the transboundary and national water resources management. The Position Paper for the Swaziland Tripartite Partnership Technical Committee (TPTC) was produced, which instrument was enabled by the Climate Change Impacts Assessment Transboundary Water Resources Management Report bringing recommendations for presentation in the next sitting of the TPTC (South Africa and Mozambique) for CCA integrated policy reform.
4. Advocacy and awareness creation on climate change adaptation (CCA) and its linkages with sustainable development was demonstrated during the 2015 World Water Day. Awareness for rural communities for adoption of practices through water harvesting was promoted for example the sand dams supply to the local clinic was demonstrated at KaBhudla community. Further demonstration were on the sand dams supplying water for vegetable growing through the climate smart agriculture drip irrigation technology.

1. 2 Water Sector Coordination quarterly meetings, facilitating dissemination of at least 4 CCA KM products; World Water Day commemoration. 2. At least 30 Community members trained on aquaculture; 30 community members trained in horticulture. 3. One (1) training workshop conducted for the TPTC Swaziland delegation; One River Basin Authorities workshop conducted for climate change adaptation in the water sector. 4. Terminal Evaluation Report for the GEF PIMS 3603 with climate change adaptation lessons. 5. Two (2) MOU/A signed with national for increased sustainability of project outcomes beyond the project life. 6. Emergency support capacities for the impacts of El Nino: Emergency water trucking and harvesting infrastructure in selected schools and health facilities.

description.narrative: 1.3: Institutional needs for inter-sectoral cooperation identified (through national dialogue - Output 1.2), appropriate national inter-sectoral coordination mechanism clearly defined, establishment/ strengthening of national coordination mechanism supported and capacity of key staff/ stakeholders strengthened through at least three (3) targeted training courses on inter-sectoral coordination

comment.narrative: 1.3 Inter-sectoral coordination needs and mechanisms not clearly defined, National Climate Change Committee not gazetted and with limited competencies to guide adaptation option in the country.

1.3: Institutional needs for inter-sectoral cooperation identified (through national dialogue - Output 1.2), appropriate national inter-sectoral coordination mechanism clearly defined, establishment/ strengthening of national coordination mechanism supported and capacity of key staff/ stakeholders strengthened through at least three (3) targeted training courses on inter-sectoral coordination

The key outputs of this activity were mostly achieved in the 2014/15 reporting period.
During this reporting period, the Project has facilitated greater integration of the water sector issues in the work of the National Climate Change Committee and further develop plans to incorporate climate change in a sector wide approach.
The project has strengthened the coordination and inclusion of climate change into the sector wide approach within the Ministry of Natural Resources and Energy.
The Ministry of Natural Resources and Energy has further established a coordinated reporting system for which climate change is one of the key pillars feeding into the National Planning and Reporting Processes and frameworks in the Ministry of Natural Resources and Energy.

description.narrative: Promote the implementation of national and trans-boundary integrated water resource management that is sustainable and equitable given expected climate change.

Institutional capacity for climate change adaptation strengthened through the integration of climate change risks into national water resources management policies and the establishment of inter-sectoral- coordination mechanims based on inclusive and informed national dialogue

1.1: Key scientific knowledge gaps on climate change impacts within the water sector defined, targeted research to fill knowledge gaps carried out, climate change response options identified, and main findings and strategic recommendations disseminated to at least twenty (20) relevant organisations across sectors (incl. KOBWA, MNRE, MoA, MoEPD, MoF, MoH, MoPSI, MTEA, NCCC, NDMA, NMS, NWA, RBAs, SEA, SWADE, SZWP, TPTC)

comment.narrative: 1.1 Information in Swaziland on climate change risks and possible impacts is scarce, particularly regarding flood vulnerability, groundwater potential and crop diversification options

1.1: Key scientific knowledge gaps on climate change impacts within the water sector defined, targeted research to fill knowledge gaps carried out, climate change response options identified, and main findings and strategic recommendations disseminated to at least twenty (20) relevant organisations across sectors (incl. KOBWA, MNRE, MoA, MoEPD, MoF, MoH, MoPSI, MTEA, NCCC, NDMA, NMS, NWA, RBAs, SEA, SWADE, SZWP, TPTC)

The key baseline studies and knowledge gaps on climate change impacts for the water sector were conducted and completed during the 2013/14 reporting period. The Third National Communications to the UNFCCC for Swaziland supported by UNEP analytic base has already benefitted from the 2014 CC Vulnerability Assessment Report facilitated by the Project. Information packaging is currently underway through the development of abridged versions and new products for different users in particular, decision makers, the various technical institutions, vulnerable community members and women. These will be shared with stakeholders in various platforms such as meetings, public offices, electronically and through the webpage. The products include:
Summarized versions of all the key project reports (the vulnerability assessment, crop diversification study, groundwater study and policy and institutional dialogues report)
Project Policy brief report based on report outcomes.
Lessons learnt report
Technical Knowledge sharing products in both English and local language (Siswati): through pamphlets, brochures for sand dams, rainwater harvesting and ecosystem restoration
Development of a video on sand dams construction, maintenance and use.
Development of a scientific paper on sand dams technology for information sharing with the academia and other partners.
This will increase the visibility of the project and spread the successful story of the project impacts. The Outputs will also be shared in both the UNDP website and the Government (DWA) new project website currently being developed. The targeted institutions include: KOBWA, MNRE, MoA, MoEPD, MoF, MoH, MoPSI, MTEA, NCCC, NDMA, NMS, NWA, RBAs, SEA, SWADE, SZWP, TPTC). Some of the products will target other stakeholders like communities and local traditional leaders.

description.narrative: 1.2: A set of tailor-made climate change response measures related to national (and trans-boundary) water management identified and integrated into at least three (3) national level policies related to water resources management (e.g. NWP, IWRMP, draft National Climate Change Policy) through a series of national policy dialogue workshops (incl. with organisations listed under Output 1.1 and using strategic recommendations from that output)

comment.narrative: 1.2 Key national policies do not, or not adequately, consider climate change

1.2: A set of tailor-made climate change response measures related to national (and trans-boundary) water management identified and integrated into at least three (3) national level policies related to water resources management (e.g. NWP, IWRMP, draft National Climate Change Policy) through a series of national policy dialogue workshops (incl. with organisations listed under Output 1.1 and using strategic recommendations from that output)

1.2.1 - The project has facilitated climate change issues in the water sector in overall. The climate change response measures that were identified in a participatory manner involving all key stakeholders culminated into the drafting of policy statements for inclusion in the water sector related policies. The scientific evidence and outputs of the project vulnerability assessments were used as a reference point in the formulation of the following policies:
Final draft of the Climate Change Policy developed in 2014.
Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan 2014-2018 incorporating adaptation measures for the water sector completed in 2013/14.
Policy statements on climate change adaptation for inclusion in the following water sector strategic documents were developed: 2003 National Water Policy and the IWRM Master Plan. These statement briefs are utilized by the DWA in a review process for integration of climate change through an EU funded project. The Emergency Preparedness Plans for the major dams in Swaziland Reports were produced .These are currently being utilized by the DWA to inform the new country Dam Safety Regulations that are under formulation. The project outputs have also been instrumental in informing the drafting of the Third National Communication to the UNFCCC and the Intended National Determined Contributions (INDCs) Report to be submitted to UN in October. The PMU serves in the technical working group to facilitate supply of climate change adaptation and mitigation information for the water sector.

description.narrative: Climate change risk management measures integrated into national water and agricultural programmes and implemented in pilot projects to promote adaptation on the ground

2.1: Guidelines for mainstreaming climate change risks into key national policies (NWP, IWRMP, NCCP) developed, toolkits on practical application of climate change response measures (identified through Output 1.2) developed and at least five (5) targeted training courses on toolkit application delivered

comment.narrative: 2.1 Key national policies do not, or not adequately, consider climate change and inadequate knowledge on practical implementation of climate change response measures

2.1: Guidelines for mainstreaming climate change risks into key national policies (NWP, IWRMP, NCCP) developed, toolkits on practical application of climate change response measures (identified through Output 1.2) developed and at least five (5) targeted training courses on toolkit application delivered

2.1.1 - 2.1.3 The final guidelines for mainstreaming climate change and toolkits for practical implementation of climate for the water and land use sector were developed and finalised in collaboration with the key stakeholders. Recommendations for Policy statements for climate change mainstreaming were developed for inclusion into the following national policies:
Water sector policies (IWRM Master Plan, National Water Policy
National Land Policy
Review of the Environment Impact Assessment Regulatory Framework
Comprehensive Agricultural Sector Policy
In addition, various tools for practical application of climate change response measures for water and land use were developed. The tools included: Digital agriculture & amp; Land use Toolkit – Version 1.0 – December 2014; The Climate Mapper; CRISTAL; Climate Vulnerability and Capacity Analysis Tool (cvca); Climate Change Monitoring Tool; WEAP; Mike Basin; SCADA; and,Standard Precipitation Index 40. Upon validation of the reports, stakeholders were engaged in a training on the practical use of these tools to foster understanding and technical skilling.

description.narrative: 2.2: Programme/ project specific climate change risks and tailor-made response measures identified and integrated into at least three (3) major management/ investment plans implemented in Swaziland (incl. KDDP, LUSIP and CDPs developed under the FAO-GEF SLM programme implemented by SWADE)

comment.narrative: 2.2 Climate change risks and possible response measures at present not considered in national management/ investment plans

2.2: Programme/ project specific climate change risks and tailor-made response measures identified and integrated into at least three (3) major management/ investment plans implemented in Swaziland (incl. KDDP, LUSIP and CDPs developed under the FAO-GEF SLM programme implemented by SWADE)

Increased resilience for the sugar industry, which accounts for a significant proportion of the GDP (18-21% of the GDP) has been climate-proofed. The project has successfully identified specific climate change risks and tailor made response measures for the three major investments in Swaziland through the development of Emergency Preparedness Plans (drought and floods) for the three major dam infrastructures in Swaziland; Maguga, Mjoli and Lubovane Dams for KOBWA, Komati Downstream Development Project (KDDP) and the LUSIP project, respectively.
The intervention aimed at building the capacities for risk management with focus on improving the technical staff and downstream communities’ awareness on the future anticipated impacts of climate change. This has culminated into the development of Dam Safety Regulations for the major Dams operated by the three institutions, highlighted above.
Through the project interventions, climate change tailor made response measures were recommended for the two SWADE projects (LUSIP and KDDP) and also for the LUSIP-GEF project community Development Plans. A number of climate change recommendations for each investment plan was identified for implementation by SWADE and other key stakeholders. These recommendations were discussed with senior management of SWADE in order to develop an action plan to address a responsive undertaking towards mitigating potential impacts. The commitment demonstrated by SWADE to address the recommendations was evident in translating lessons into the development of the chiefdom development plans and environment mitigation plans.

description.narrative: 2.3: Capacity of key stakeholders and water resources management and/or agricultural development practitioners to integrate climate change risks into their activities strengthened by incorporating the climate risks/responses measures (identified under Output 2.2) into the ongoing training courses offerd as part of ongoing national programmes (e.g. KDDP, LUSIP).

comment.narrative: 2.3 Knowledge and awareness of climate change risks is very low and climate change risk is not adequately considered in ongoing implementation of ongoing activities

2.3: i) Climate change adaptation modules developed for train-the-trainers courses based on risks/responses identified under Output 2.2 to raise trainers awareness and capacity on CCA; ii) at least two forthcoming training courses are strengthened through the inclusion of CCA modules in the training materials, and iii) strengthened training courses offered to build awareness and capacity of practitioners

Fifteen (15) new climate change adaptation modules were developed under Output 2.2. About 13 of the modules are dealing with agricultural extension and agribusiness, incorporating climate smart agriculture (CSA) practices and new agronomic practices in the light of climate change. The modules also focus on the key cash crops that are produced in the country in light of the diversification options: Cassava, vegetables etc. Some of the modules focused on IWRM management and improving irrigation efficiency at the farm level as well as rainwater harvesting in and outside the farm. An environmental module was also developed focusing on the environmental aspects in the project.
A consultative approach was utilised in the development of the climate smart modules to be utilised through a Training of Trainers modality, however some modules would have to facilitate a contact modality, in particular training of the farmers. Thirty-five (35) SWADE Trainers, composed of community environmental officers and SWADE agricultural extension officers were trained on the modules which was also open for the communities' lead farmers. The trainings were not only limited to the modules but also covered the aspects of revised chiefdom development plans guidelines taking into account climate change impacts.

description.narrative: 2.4: Community based climate resilience projects implemented in pilot sites, including the installation of rainwater harvesting systems in at least four (4) identified communities/ areas and rainwater infiltration improvement schemes (incl. reforestation) in at least four (4) communities/areas

comment.narrative: 2.4 Climate change risk awareness and adaptation capacity at community level is very low

2.4.1/2: The impacts of the rainwater harvesting systems installed in schools and communities were monitored during the reporting period together with the lessons documentation. The activities also included training in six (6) schools for teachers, students, school committees, constituency leaders, community health motivators, community water management committees and traditional community leaders. In total there were 256 trained people of which 58% were women. The training did not only focus on rainwater harvesting but also considered an integrated approach to environmental and natural resources management. Knowledge sharing and good practice was instilled among the school children through establishment of schools water, sanitation and environmental groups to champion the management of the harvested water and productive use of excess and waste water through fruit tree growing (the trees were also provided by the project)
Key impacts that are monitored include: improvement on sanitation issues (diahorreal reports at neighboring clinics), absenteeism’s due to water related challenges, and this will also be included in the lessons learnt documentation under development.
2.4.3/5: The community capacities for ecosystem restoration continue being enabled on the ground. The activities achieved and completed so far include: Integrated approach to removal of Alien invasive plans covering an area more than 50ha; Artificial means to improve rainwater infiltration through trenching and terracing; Establishment of livelihood projects that are climate smart and less dependent on natural resources such as, establishment of vegetable nursery, fruit tree plantation integrated with bee keeping, and; 5ha drip irrigation and fish production.
Ownership of the intervention continues being embedded in community participation. Partnership with other institutions such as the National Agricultural Marketing Board (NAMBoard) has been established to provide sustainable extension and marketing services to the community schemes as well as Ministry of Agriculture extension department and non-government organization - World Vision for continued providing of support to the community. The project is also providing continuous training in leadership to foster sustainability, in particular for the participating women.

description.narrative: Outcome 2

comment.narrative: Install Basic Weather Station at LUSIP Phase 1 and KDDP

2.4.6 -The installation of the automated weather stations at the two project sites (LUSIP 1 and KDDP) was completed 2013/14. The purpose of the stations was to expand the data availability to farmers can use for planning for climate change and also provide data for early warning systems. The collected data has been linked to National Grid at the National Meteorological Service (MET) and has contributed to the expansion of the national weather stations network. The stations have generated reliable climate and weather data for the past two years, increasing MET's capacity to provide consistent meteorological services to its users in particular as the country intends to conduct modelling scenarios. The stations have also been coded and linked with the South African Weather stations and these are known as (Sihhoye and Lubovane Weather Stations). The Data that is obtained from these stations include: Temperature, Sunshine, Relative humidity, Pressure, Rainfall, Wind speed and direction and evaporation data. All the data is automated except for the evaporation data. A data backup system has also been upgraded by the project at the National Meteorological Service through the mobile network, making it easier and more cost-effective to collect and monitor inconsistences. The MET technicians have been trained on the system and linked to the South African Weather Service for continuous support and maintenance of the stations. The Government of Swaziland has also set aside a budget for the continuous maintenance of the system. In addition to the installed instruments, the project provided additional spare parts tools that can run the system for the next 5 years.
2.4.7 The development of curriculum for schools has been left as a prerogative of the National Meteorological Office which is responsible for climate change coordination at National Level. The Project Board and Technical Committee recommended that this activity be led by the NMS and the project provide the resources. The MTR recommended that if the NMS is not able to utilize the funds by year end, the resources will be re-allocated to another activity. The Project however has continued to lobby the NMS to conduct the activity. The National Curriculum Centre provisionally agreed to engage on this activity and the process is at its infancy.

description.narrative: OUTCOME 2

comment.narrative: No CCA measures that increase water security by the utilization of a sand dam have been tested in Swaziland.
Determine feasibility sites for the installation of sand dams and to construct at least 5 pilot dams

2.4.2 - The project has successfully piloted 5 sand dams across the driest areas in the Lowveld of Swaziland. The two outstanding Dams at Sitilo and Sigwe were completed during the reporting period. The total estimated beneficiaries are 6,711 of which 52% are women. The sand dams have been very key in highlighting CCA in the country. Close collaboration with the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) and Department of Water Affairs (DWA) as well as with the five communities that participated and contributed towards their establishment in both monetary contributions and providing labor. The existing collaboration of the MOA and DWA has yielded positively on the impact even at political levels. The Minister of Agriculture and Minister of Natural Resources and Energy have officially embraced this technology through an official opening during the 2015 World Water Day Commemoration event that was held at the Mafutseni (for the KaBhudla Sand Dam) where there was demonstrated linkages between the water and health sectors. The sand dams has facilitated water supply to the newly constructed KaBhudla Clinic. The DWA is continuing to provide the necessary monitoring of the water quality through laboratory analysis of the water and also monitoring the water quantity. The communities are being assisted to put up a proposal for Government to fund pumping of the water from the dams and provide it for both establishment drip irrigated gardens and for potable water supply to the various surrounding communities.
The lessons learnt and full scale impact including a gender analysis report is still being conducted for future reporting.

description.narrative: Negotiations on trans-boundary water management for the Incomati, Maputo and Umbeluzi river basins informed by climate change risk analysis.

3.1: Climate change impacts on trans-boundary water resource management (TWRM) and negotiation options assessed, tailor-made (short-, mid- and long-term) TWRM strategy paper for Swaziland developed through consultations with key stakeholders (as integral part of national policy dialogue - Output 1.2) and position paper for Swaziland TWRM negotation team(s) jointly developed (with negotiators)

comment.narrative: 3.1 Present water agreements (on Incomati, Maputo) do not adequately address climate change and adaptation

3.1: Climate change impacts on trans-boundary water resource management (TWRM) and negotiation options assessed, tailor-made (short-, mid- and long-term) TWRM strategy paper for Swaziland developed through consultations with key stakeholders (as integral part of national policy dialogue - Output 1.2) and position paper for Swaziland TWRM negotation team(s) jointly developed (with negotiators)

3.1.1 - 3.2.2 The project has continued to engage with the TPTC and negotiating bodies at national level. A consensus has been reached that this component is very essential both within the country and at the transboundary level. The project has facilitated the engagement of both local and international consultants to assist in developing the position and strategy paper informing the delegation to the TPTC. A model for water and demand management is currently being established for the three major basins (Komati, Mbuluzi and Usuthu). Data collection is underway among the various entities and institutions. The inception phase of the study has been completed. The team of consultants are currently working on the modelling of various climate change scenarios that will inform the position of the country and further inform the strategy that will focus the country on CCA IWRM, as well as conducting stakeholder’s consultation at various levels including the transboundary levels. The final outputs are expected in October 2015, upon which the engagement of the riparian countries to discuss the outcome will be solicited. The process has received political support from the Minister of Natural Resources and Energy. The capacity of the TPTC negotiating team will also be built through training through utilization of the project outputs like the climate change vulnerability assessment for the water sector and infrastructure.

description.narrative: 3.2: Targeted information briefs on projected climate change impacts on TWRM developed and disseminated to senior decision-makers in at least twenty (20) relevant organisations, including key water user groups

comment.narrative: 3.2 Stakeholder knowledge and awareness on climate change impacts on TWRM is very limited

3.2: Targeted information briefs on projected climate change impacts on TWRM developed and disseminated to senior decision-makers in at least twenty (20) relevant organisations, including key water user groups

3.2.1 -3.2.2 – The project has continued to provide the necessary information briefs to the government, key institutions and national stakeholders. Leadership of the 2015 World Water Day by DWA was facilitated through by Project resulting in information through pamphlets, print media articles on the importance of water to the achievement of MDGs and sustainable development. The project has developed a lessons learnt report that has been shared with the key stakeholders. A consultant has been engaged to focus on the development and packaging of the information sharing documents. The Inception report for the communication strategy has been adopted. The project will develop abridged versions of all the reports produced by the project consultants and document lessons from all the project interventions for sharing with stakeholders at various levels and platforms. Information will also be shared electronically through a webpage, and on Facebook, YouTube and twitter. A scientific research paper on the sand dams work done by the project is also being packaged as part of the information sharing to stakeholders.

description.narrative: Strengthening Capacity for Environmental Sustainability and Climate Change.

title.narrative: Environment Sustainability & Climate Change Project Document

description.narrative: Improved enabling environment for climate change and risks integration.
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. National Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan in place by 2013 2. National Climate Change Policy in place by 2014 3. Number of community resilience initaitives supported: National Disaster Simulation Excercise, World Disaster Day etc 4. Number of national capacity building intiatives for enhanced management and monitoring of natural resources.

comment.narrative: 1. Limited enabling environment for national climate change undertaking: no national frameworks or ingration of climate change into sectoral approches. 2. Disaster risk management not promoted fully: limited resources. 3. Limited capacity to manage natural resources sustainably.

1. National Climate Change Policy approved 2. Environmental Education Association of Southern Africa Regional Conference supported. 3. Strategic Environment Impact Assessment and Audit Regulations reviewed 4. Advocacy and resources mobilisation for adaptation, mitigation and waste management and the SE4All initiatives 5. National Climate Change Committee programme management capacities enhanced.

1. The National Climate Change Policy draft approved by the Ministry of Tourism and Environmental Affairs (MTEA) increased the resilience road-mapping response to the impact of climate change and variability in the country. The Policy also proposes institutional arrangement and management of climate finance strengthening the readiness of the country to receive, utilize and account for the global resources.
2. The participation of the 16 youth in the Environment Education Association of Southern Africa: “Recommitting to Building Sustainable Societies beyond the UN Decade on Education for Sustainable Development Regional Conference hosted by the Swaziland Environmental Authority (SEA) in September 2015. The Conference highlighted the need to prioritize programmes promoting professional inclusion of the youth, within the catalytic role of the environment as a service to sustainable development (jobs and entrepreneurship).
3. The Environment Impact Assessment and Environment Audit Regulations were reviewed. The new Regulation Frameworks enabled the integration of social, gender and HIV and AIDS in all the development plan, in particular large projects and programmes. The review facilitated the Swaziland Environment Authority cost-recovery through the EIA fees review as well as provided guidance on the undertaking of Strategic EIA.
4. The Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) Gap Analysis Report and Action Plan 2014-2030 was approved by the Government of Swaziland resulting in a high-level launch that created awareness on the use of Renewable Energy for production of electricity. The Report launch was undertaken together with the 2014 Renewables Readiness Assessment (RRA) Report for Swaziland supported by the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA).
The SE4ALL Investment Prospectus and the Actions Agenda (IP-AA) draft has been prepared and subjected to the Quality Assurance review by the Africa Regional Hub. Further consultations have been suggested with the in

1. National capacities through enhanced frameworks for climate change management: draft Climate Change Bill; National Adaptation Plan (NAP). 2. Sustainable Energy for ALL Investment Prospectus and Actions Agenda (IP-AA) for an engaged national stakeholders for increased uptake of renewable energy production and private sector involvement. 3. Two 'waste for jobs' pilot schemes in place. 4. Increased national and local capacities for disaster risk management: 5 local governments contingency plans; national standard operating procedures. 5. Coordinated Emergency and Early Recovery capacities for the impacts of El Nino: 5 Trainings for effective coordination of NERMAP; Communication and KM products.

description.narrative: Upscaling of climate smart agriculture in Swaziland. This will include piloting of conservation agriculture, water efficient irrigation technologies and high value marketing options.

participating-org.narrative: Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA)

title.narrative: UNDP NAMBoard NIM LOA and Attachments
Mpatheni Community members laying the main lines from dam to irrigated fields

description.narrative: Pilot programme for Upscaling Conservation Agriculture, Water Efficient Irrigation Technologies and High Value Crops Marketing.

participating-org.narrative: Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA)

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

provider-org.narrative: Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA)
Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA)

description.narrative: a) Number of technical specialists / consultants providing assistance b)Number of times Admin costs paid, Amount paid c) Amount paid for transportation costs land with functional drip irrigation Planters purchased d) Boom Sprayers Purchased e) Number of farmers that have received input loans f) Sets of harvesting material purchased g) Number of facilities rehabilitated h) Number of refrigerated trucks purchased i) Cold Chain facilities operational j) Number of staff trained (ToT) k) Number of champion farmers trained l) Number of Farmers Trained m) Number of demonstration plots established n) Number of visits facilitated o) Baseline study conducted p) Number of monitoring visits conducted, q) Number of Monthly Reports submitted r) Number of Quarterly Reports submitted s) Final Report Submitted t) Project Evaluated u) Number of publications documented and disseminated

comment.narrative: 1. No baseline on climate smart agriculture programming in the country that will provide adaptation options for cropping, livestock, and combinations, with costed actions to improve sustainability. 2. No water saving technologies producing high value crops that are market oriented and synchronised with marketing calendar and directly linked to markets through NAMBoard and partners for the Mpatheni, Nkhungwini and Nhlentjeni areas. 3. Limited capacity for local farmers in use of climate smart agricultural technologies including CA, drip irrigation and marketing of produce for household income generation.

1. Increased capacities for the uptake of Conservation Agriculture and Climate Smart Agriculture techniques in three (3) rural, vulnerable communities of Mpatheni, Nkhungwini and Nhletjeni for income generation livelihood: Number of demonstration plots established, Number of learning visits conducted, and; Number of farmers trained in CA and CSA techniques. 2. Revolving funds accessed for income generations: Number of farmers that have received input loans

1. Three (3) exchange visits were conducted for technical uptake by 90 rural Mpatheni farmers resulting in the establishment and utilization of two (2) pilots at Mpatheni, demonstrating on Climate Smart Agriculture (CSA). Support was also provided for the adoption of the CSA and business management skills through training of 93 ‘Champion Farmers’. A total of 406 rural farmers also gained skills in post-harvest handling techniques through training by the National Marketing Board.
2. Following the establishment of the Revolving Fund in 2014, 24 farmers were able to access the financial resources to purchase inputs for the growing of vegetables, (CSA Report, 2015)

1. Increased capacities for the uptake of Conservation Agriculture and Climate Smart Agriculture techniques in three (3) rural, vulnerable communities of Mpatheni, Nkhungwini and Nhletjeni: Increased hectorage planted by the rural farmers under the Mpatheni Scheme (80%) of the 32ha and enhanced livelihoods for 56 households. 2. Increased sustainability of the income generation options established through the CSA Project: Increased repayments from the 25% to 50% of the rural farmers loan from the revolving fund. 3. Terminal Evaluation Report for the Climate Smart Agriculture Project.

description.narrative: To strengthen the management effectiveness of the Protected Area system of Swaziland to ensure a viable set of representative samples of the country’s full range of natural ecosystems are conserved, through a network of PAs.

title.narrative: 4932 Swaziland BGP SNTC MoU Final signed copy

description.narrative: To strengthen the management effectiveness of the Protected Area system of Swaziland to ensure a viable set of representative samples of the country’s full range of natural ecosystems are conserved, through a network of PAs.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

comment.narrative: 1. Protected Area Coverage - 3.9% 2. Limited national capacities for systemitised knowledge base and PA management. 3. Low invetsment through landscape approach.
1. Project Management Unit in place by June 2015. 2. Inception meeting convened and Report approved. 3. Baseline GIS-based assessments initiated

1. Extensive advocacy consultation brought more awareness on conservation management through Protected Areas by the traditional leaders in all the four (4) Regions of the country. 26 Chiefdoms with 409 community members and 13 private land owners identified biodiversity management initiatives that can contribute to job creation, were consulted on the GEF-funded SNPAS Project. The SNPAS Project Management Unit comprising of 9 staff members was established together with the Project Steering Committee and the Project Board, structures that will promote the uptake of systemic conservation management in the country.
2. Evidence generation for conservation management through the Knowledge-based GIS biodiversity System for the country was initiated. Technical support was engaged and drafted inception reports on how the work for the integrated biodiversity and sustainable financing, legal and land-use assessments would be facilitated by rural communities in 2016/2017.

1. Biodiversity data and information generation and management enhanced in the country through assessment reports: Integrated Biodiversity: Sustainable Financing: Socio-Economic Profile and Protected Areas Feasibility; Assessment Report; Vegetation and Land-use cover Maps. 2. GIS knowledge-based system in place. 3. Six (6) Gazettes drafted for expansion of protected areas in the country. 4. Increased engagement and involvement of rural communities and private sector in biodiversity management through protected areas: Four (4) partnership established; 75% of the 26 Chiefdoms trained in Chiefdom Development Plans and developing the CPDs with an integration of conservation management.
